facts.text: Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 55 of 1954 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 55 of 1954. Under article 32 of the Constitution for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: C. Chatterjee, J. B. Dadachanji and Rajinder Narain appeared for the petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: C. Chatterjee,  J. B. Dadachanji and Rajinder Narain, with him  for the petitioners.

facts.text: V. Tambe and I. N. Shroff appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: V. Tambe and I. N. Shroff for the respondent.

facts.text: The case was heard on April 5, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. April 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J.-
The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J.-This is a petition under article 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: Petitioner No. 1 was an Agricultural Demonstrator of the Government of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Petitioner No. I before us was an Agricultural Demonstrator of the Government of Madras and was employed as an Assistant Marketing Officer

facts.text: Petitioner No. 1 was employed as an Assistant Marketing Officer in Central Provinces and Berar for the purchase and movement of blackgram and other grains on behalf of the Madras Government.

anchor.surface_text: and was employed as an Assistant Marketing Officer in Central Provinces and Berar for the purchase and movement of blackgram and other grains on behalf of the Madras Government.

facts.text: Petitioner No. 1, second petitioner and 44 others are under prosecution before Shri K. E. Pandey, Special Magistrate of Nagpur, Madhya Pradesh, in Case No. I of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: He, as well as the second petitioner and 44 others, are under prosecution before Shri K. E. Pandey, a Special Magistrate of Nagpur, Madhya Pradesh, in Case No. I of 1949 pending before him

facts.text: Prosecution on charges of cheating, attempt to commit cheating, criminal breach of trust and criminal conspiracy under sections 420 read with 120-B or 109 IPC, 409 IPC and 409 read with 120-B IPC.

anchor.surface_text: on charges of cheating, attempt to companymit cheating, criminal breach of trust and criminal companyspiracy,  i.e., for offences punishable under section 420 read with section 120-B or 109 of the Indian Penal Code, section 409

facts.text: Allegation that acts committed by the accused caused the Government of Madras to incur excess expenditure of Rs. 3,57,147-10-0.

anchor.surface_text: and the allegation is that by reason of the acts companymitted by the accused, the Government of Madras had to incur an expenditure of Rs. 3,57,147-10-0 in excess of the amount due.

facts.text: Special Magistrate appointed by Madhya Pradesh Government under section 14 of CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Magistrate before whom the case is number pending was appointed by the Madhya Pradesh Government under section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code,

facts.text: Prosecution against first petitioner initiated by sanction given by Government of Madras under section 197(1) of CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: and as the first petitioner was a servant of the Government of Madras, the prosecution against him has been initiated by sanction given by the Government of Madras under section 197 1  of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: The trial has not yet commenced.

anchor.surface_text: it is admitted that the trial has number yet companymenced.

facts.text: Shri K. L. Pandey was first appointed as Special Magistrate for the trial, later appointed as acting Sessions Judge and ceased to have the case, then reverted to original post.

anchor.surface_text: that in the present case Shri K. L. Pandey who was first appointed as a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case, and to whose file on such appointment this case was transferred, was later on appointed as acting Sessions Judge for some time and ceased to have this case before him.

facts.text: Questions raised before High Court by applications under Article 226 and decided against petitioners; no appeals taken to this Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is desirable to observe that the questions above dealt with appear to have been raised before the High Court at previous stages by means of applications under article 226 and decided against. No appeals to this Court have been taken against the orders therein.

concepts.unlisted_description: Sanction for prosecution of public servant

issues.text: Whether Section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code, in so far as it authorises the Provincial Government to confer upon any person all or any of the powers conferred or conferrable by or under the Code on a Magistrate of the first, second or third class in respect of particular cases and thereby to constitute a Special Magistrate for the trial of an individual case, violates the guarantee under article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code, in so far as it authorises the Provincial Government to confer upon any person all or any of the powers conferred or conferrable by or under the Code on a Magistrate of the first, second or third class in respect of particular cases and thereby to constitute a Special Magistrate for the trial of an individual case, violates the guarantee under article 14 of the Constitution

issues.text: Whether the sanction given under section 197(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code for the prosecution as against the first petitioner is invalid, inasmuch as the order of the Madras Government granting the sanction does not disclose that all the facts constituting the offences to be charged were placed before the sanctioning authority nor does the sanction state the time or place of the occurrence or the transactions involved in it, or the persons with whom the offences were committed

anchor.surface_text: The sanction given under section 197 1 of the Criminal Procedure Code for the prosecution as against the first petitioner is invalid, inasmuch as the order of the Madras Government granting the sanction does not disclose that all the facts constituting the offences to be charged were placed before the sanctioning authority nor does the sanction state the time or place of the occurrence or the transactions involved in it, or the persons with whom the offences were committed. This contention is raised relying on the Privy Council case in Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King

issues.text: Whether, even if the sanction under section 197(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code is valid, it is for the very Government which accords the sanction to specify also the Court before which the trial is to be held under section 197(2) and in the absence of any such specification by the said Government, the power under section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code of appointing a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case cannot be exercised by the Madhya Pradesh Government

anchor.surface_text: Even if the sanction under section 197 1 of the Criminal Procedure Code is valid, it is for the very Government which accords the sanction to specify also the Court before which the trial is to be held under section 197 2 and in the absence -of any such specification by the said Government, the power under section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code of appointing a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case cannot be exercised by the Madhya Pradesh Government.

issues.text: Whether in the present case Shri K. L. Pandey who was first appointed as a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case, and to whose file on such appointment this case was transferred, was later on appointed as acting Sessions Judge for some time and ceased to have this case before him. He reverted back from his position as acting Sessions Judge to his original post. Without a fresh notification appointing him as Special Magistrate and transferring the case to him as such, he can be said to be seized of this case as Special Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: In addition to the above three points, learned counsel for the petitioners has also raised a further point that in the present case Shri K. L. Pandey who was first appointed as a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case, and to whose file on such appointment this case was transferred, was later on appointed as acting Sessions Judge for some time and ceased to have this case before him. He reverted back from his position as acting Sessions Judge to his original post.

arguments.claim: Section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code, in so far as it authorises the Provincial Government to confer upon any person all or any of the powers conferred or conferrable by or under the Code on a Magistrate of the first, second or third class in respect of particular cases and thereby to constitute a Special Magistrate for the trial of an individual case, violates the guarantee under article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code, in so far as it authorises the Provincial Government to confer upon any person all or any of the powers conferred or conferrable by or under the Code on a Magistrate of the first, second or third class in respect of particular cases and thereby to constitute a Special Magistrate for the trial of an individual case, violates the guarantee under article 14 of the Constitution

arguments.claim: The decision in Anwar Ali Sarkar's case applies only to a case where... discrimination arises... prejudicing them thereby. In the present case, the Special Magistrate under section 14... has to try the case entirely under the normal procedure, and no discrimination... arises here

anchor.surface_text: In support of the objection raised under article 14 of the Constitution, reliance is placed on the decision of this Court in Anwar Ali Sarkars case 1 . That decision, however, applies only to a case where on the allotment of an. individual case to a special Court authorised to conduct the trial by a procedure substantially different from the normal procedure, discrimination arises

arguments.claim: A law vesting discretion in an authority under such circumstances cannot be said to be discriminatory as such, and is therefore not hit by article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: A law vesting discretion in an authority under such circumstances cannot be said to be discriminatory as such, and is therefore not hit by article 14 of the Constitution. There is, therefore, no substance in this contention.

arguments.claim: The Privy Council itself... has recognised that the lacunas, if any, in the sanction... can be remedied in the course of the trial by the specific evidence in that behalf

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council itself in the case mentioned above has recognised that the lacunas, if any, in the sanction of the kind contemplated by that decision can be remedied in the course of the trial by the specific evidence in that behalf.

arguments.claim: The power under section 197(2)... is a permissive power... The one relates to the Court and the other to the Person. Under sub-section (2) of section 197, the sanctioning Government may specify a Court... but... such specification of the Court does not touch the question as to who is the person to function in such Court

anchor.surface_text: The contention of learned counsel for the petitioners is based on sub-section 2 of section 197... The argument is that it is for the very Government which sanctioned the prosecution under section 197 1 to specify the Court... The power under section 197 2 appears to be vested... The one relates to the Court and the other to the Person.

arguments.claim: There is accordingly no substance in this contention

anchor.surface_text: There is accordingly no substance in this contention.

arguments.claim: All the points raised on behalf of the petitioners fail, and this petition must be dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In the result, all the points raised on behalf of the petitioners fail, and this petition must be dismissed.

holdings.text: A law vesting discretion in an authority under such circumstances cannot be said to be discriminatory as such, and is therefore not hit by article 14 of the Constitution. There is, therefore, no substance in this contention.

anchor.surface_text: A law vesting discretion in an authority under such circumstances cannot be said to be discriminatory as such, and is therefore not hit by article 14 of the Constitution. There is, therefore, nosubstance in this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Anwar Ali Sarkar case as Special Magistrate tries case under normal procedure with no discrimination between offenders subjected to different procedures.

holdings.text: It is, therefore, unnecessary to decide the point whether or not the sanction, as it is, and without such evidence is invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council itself in the case mentioned above has recognised that the lacunas, if any, in the sanction of the kind contemplated by that decision can be remedied in the course of the trial by the specific evidence in that behalf. Learned counsel for the State, without conceding the objection raised, has mentioned to us that evidence in that behalf will be given at the trial. It is, therefore, unnecessary to decide the point whether or not the sanction, as it is, and without such evidence is invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial not commenced; Privy Council in Gokulchand recognizes lacunas in sanction can be remedied by evidence at trial; State will adduce evidence.

holdings.text: There is accordingly nosubstance in this contention.

anchor.surface_text: The argument of learned counsel proceeds on treating the word Court in sub-section 2 of section 197 as being the same as a person in sub-section 1 of section 14, for which there is nowarrant. There is accordingly nosubstance in this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 197(2) permissive power to specify court (not person functioning as magistrate); does not exclude or imply against exercise of section 14 power by Provincial Government; scopes distinct: one court, other person.

holdings.text: In view of that statement, it is unnecessary to pronounce on the objection so raised.

anchor.surface_text: Here again, learned counsel for the State informs us, without conceding the point so taken, that he is prepared to advise the Government to issue the necessary notification and have the case transferred. In view of that statement, it is unnecessary to pronounce on the objection so raised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State counsel states prepared to issue fresh notification and transfer case; thus unnecessary to decide seizure issue.

holdings.text: In the result, all the points raised on behalf of the petitioners fail, and this petition must be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, all the points raised on behalf of the petitioners fail, and this petition must be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected or not decided adversely to petitioners.

holdings.text: It is desirable to observe that the questions above dealt with appear to have been raised before the High Court at previous stages by means of applications under article 226 and decided against. No appeals to this Court have been taken against the orders therein.

anchor.surface_text: Here again, learned counsel for the State informs us, without conceding the point so taken, that he is prepared to advise the Government to issue the necessary notification and have the case transferred. In view of that statement, it is unnecessary to pronounce on the objection so raised.
In the result, all the points raised on behalf of the petitioners fail, and this petition must be dismissed.
